conclusion: Let h be the depth of the point source S below the water surface.
Light rays of wavelength A and B travel from the source, refract at the water-air interface, and emerge into the air.
A ray that just grazes the boundary of the smaller, polychromatically illuminated circle must satisfy the critical refraction condition for light A.
For this limiting ray, the angle of refraction in air is 90°, so the angle of incidence in water equals the critical angle θc,A, with sin θc,A = 1 / n₁.
The corresponding limiting ray for wavelength B that meets the same point on the surface must make the same incidence angle in water.
Applying Snell’s law to that ray for light B gives n₂ sin θc,A = sin θB.
Substitute sin θc,A = 1 / n₁: n₂ (1 / n₁) = sin θB.
The sine of the refraction angle of monochromatic light B at the boundary of the small circular area is sin θB = n₂ / n₁.
